questions.text: An old lady developed intractable vomiting for 7 days with loss of fluid in stools, decrease food intake and developed altered sensorium. She is brought to the hospital, where fluid loss is corrected with rapid fluids and electrolyte correction is given. Few hours later, the patient started having quadriplegia and mutism. What is the likely imaging finding?
questions.solution: Ans. A

choices.text: Decreased cholecystokinin release due to lack of enteral stimulation
Decreased cholesterol conversion to bile acids due to liver dysfunction
High cholesterol content of the nutritional fluids
Inadequate supplementation of essential fatty acids

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the OPD due to acute-onset right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. The patient had an extensive small bowel resection due to bowel ischemia a year ago and has been receiving total parenteral nutrition since then. Abdominal ultrasonography is shown below. Which of the following is most likely factor responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased cholecystokinin release due to lack of enteral stimulation 


Prolonged total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and lack of enteral feeding cause decreased CCK release, leading to gallbladder stasis and bile sludge/stone formation (acalculous cholecystitis or cholesterol sludge). Stasis is the primary mechanism linking TPN to gallbladder pathology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Decreased cholesterol conversion to bile acids due to liver dysfunction: Decreased hepatic conversion of cholesterol to bile acids can worsen cholesterol supersaturation but is not the main mechanism in TPN-related stasis.

 

Option C. High cholesterol content of the nutritional fluids: High cholesterol content in TPN fluids is not a recognized cause—parenteral lipid emulsions do not directly produce gallstones via this route.

 

Option D. Inadequate supplementation of essential fatty acids: Essential fatty-acid deficiency causes systemic problems but is not the principal factor for TPN-associated gallbladder stasis.

questions.text: 5-year-old boy has developed persistent food-seeking behavior over the past few months.  This patient's food-seeking behavior could be explained by a lesion causing impairment of which hypothalamic nucleus?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Ventromedial

choices.text: RT-PCR for hepatitis C virus

questions.text:
A 42-year-old male patient presented with jaundice. His AST was 48 U, ALT was 51 U, ALP, GGT were normal. Ultrasound of liver was suggestive of cirrhosis. Viral markers were done and the following results were obtained. What is the next best step?

 

Anti-HAV: Negative

Anti-HBeAg: Negative

Anti-HBcAg IgG: Positive

Anti-HBcAg IgM :Negative

HBsAg: Negative

Anti-HbsAg: Positive

Anti-HCV: Positive
questions.solution: Ans. C. RT-PCR for hepatitis C virus

choices.text: Patient should be asked to take deep breaths
The cuff pressure should be increased to 20 mm over systolic pressure
The cuff sound be slowly deflate until the first Korotkoff sound is heard only during expiration
Pulses paradoxus may not be present

questions.text: A patient with suspected cardiac tamponade presents to the AIIMS emergency. You are asked to monitor BP of this patient. All the following precautions should be taken except:
questions.solution: Ans. A. Patient should be asked to take deep breaths

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes for evaluation of persistent morning stiffness. She was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis 4 months ago and was prescribed methotrexate. The patient currently takes the maximum tolerated dose, along with folic acid and as-needed naproxen. On examination, swelling, tenderness, and pain on range of motion are found at the metacarpophalangeal and proximal interphalangeal joints and wrists bilaterally. Treatment with etanercept is considered. Which of the following tests should be performed before beginning treatment with this agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Interferon gamma release assay

 

  • Etanercept is a TNF-α inhibitor, used in moderate-to-severe rheumatoid arthritis not responding to methotrexate.
  • TNF-α inhibitors increase the risk of reactivating latent tuberculosis (TB).
  • Screening for latent TB is mandatory before initiating therapy.
    • Options include: Tuberculin skin test (TST) or Interferon-gamma release assay (IGRA).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HRCT chest: Not required routinely before starting TNF-α inhibitors unless there is history of lung disease.

 

Option B. Echocardiogram: Only indicated if heart failure or prior cardiac history exists.

 

Option C. Fecal occult blood test: Used for colon cancer screening, not relevant for TNF-α inhibitor initiation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the OPD due to pain in multiple joints. He has a 5-year history of lumbar pain and a 2-year history of bilateral knee pain. The patient works in construction and his pain is worst after a long day on his feet. He has taken ibuprofen intermittently, but the pain is no longer tolerable. The patient has a paternal aunt with osteoarthritis. Physical examination shows blue-black spots on his sclerae and diffuse darkening of the auricular helices. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's arthritis?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Homogentisic acid dioxygenase deficiency

questions.text:
A woman came in with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness and difficulties in concentration and memory persisting for a year. During the examination, her Body Mass Index (BMI) was measured at 43 kg/m2, and her blood pressure (BP) was recorded as 170/98 mmHg. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) analysis was performed while she was awake, and the results are as follows. Based on the provided information, what is the probable diagnosis?

 

PaO2 – 70 mmHg

PaCO2 – 53 mmHg

HCO3- - 33 mmHg
questions.solution: Ans. A. Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

questions.text: All the following are seen in myasthenia gravis except:
questions.solution: Ans. B) Absent DTR

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient came with differential BP recording in the upper limb with right arm showing measurement of 150/110 mm Hg and the left showing 90/60. All of the following can be a cause except:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Coarctation of aorta

questions.text: SAAG > 1.1 in all case of ascites except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Peritoneal tuberculosis

choices.text: Nucleotide mismatches that escape repair
Covalent bonds between adjacent pyrimidines
Insertion of abnormal bases into DNA

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician with abdominal pain and melena. She also complains of progressive fatigue and a 5 kg (11 Ib) weight loss over the last 2 months. She has a strong family history of colon, endometrial, and ovarian cancer. Colonoscopy shows a protuberant, friable mass in the ascending colon, and biopsy is diagnostic for colon adenocarcinoma. Genetic analysis confirms a mutation consistent with Lynch syndrome. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the development of colon cancer in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Nucleotide mismatches that escape repair

choices.text: Atrophy and fibrous replacement of the distal esophageal muscularis propria
Diffuse eosinophil-predominant inflammation of the esophageal mucosa
Inflammation and degeneration of the esophageal myenteric plexus
Perifascicular atrophy of muscle fibers in the proximal esophageal muscularis propria

questions.text: 46-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to dysphagia. The patient has had difficulty swallowing both liquids and solid foods as well as frequent episodes of regurgitation and cough while eating. She has also had weakness in her extremities and a rash as shown below. She has difficulty lifting her arms above her head and standing from a sitting position. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's dysphagia?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Perifascicular atrophy of muscle fibers in the proximal esophageal muscularis propria

questions.text: The following gait in polio is seen due to the weakness of:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Quadriceps

questions.text: Deep y descent in JVP is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cardiac tamponade

 

Deep y descent in the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform reflects rapid early diastolic filling of the right ventricle. It is classically seen in restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM), constrictive pericarditis, and tricuspid regurgitation due to unhindered or rapid filling phases.

 

  • In cardiac tamponade, the y descent is blunted or absent because the pericardial pressure impairs early diastolic filling and equalizes diastolic pressures, leading to a slow y descent.

 

Thus, deep y descent is absent in cardiac tamponade but present in the other coditions.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain and vomiting. The patient is admitted to the hospital and treated with intravenous fluids and pain medication, but his condition fails to improve. An abdominal CT scan is shown below. The inappropriate activation of which of the following most likely initiated this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trypsinogen


Acute pancreatitis is initiated by the premature activation of trypsinogen to trypsin inside pancreatic acinar cells. Trypsin then activates other pancreatic proenzymes (eg, proelastase, prophospholipase, lipase), leading to autodigestion, necrosis, and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lipase: Causes fat necrosis in pancreatitis, but it is activated downstream after trypsin.

 

Option B. Proelastase: When activated, degrades elastic fibers in vessel walls → hemorrhage, but this occurs after trypsin activation.

 

Option C. Prophospholipase: Contributes to membrane destruction and cell necrosis, but again is dependent on trypsin.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old child was brought to OPD with a 3-day record of watery diarrhea and vomiting, displaying an altered sensorium. What possible conditions could be considered as the differential diagnoses in this case?

 

  1. Severe dehydration
  2. HUS
  3. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis
  4. Hyponatremia
questions.solution: Ans. C. 1, 3, 4

questions.text:
Which of the following diseases/ pathogens are associated with pulmonary renal syndromes?

 

  1. Goodpasture syndrome
  2. Leptospirosis
  3. Wegener’s granulomatosis
  4. Hanta virus
questions.solution: Ans. A. 1,2,3,4

questions.text: 26-year-old woman is evaluated for intermittent abdominal pain occurring over the last several years. The pain is crampy without radiation and graded 6/10 in intensity. She also has fluctuating diarrhea but has not seen blood in the stool.  Temperature is 37.2 C (99 F), blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 90/min. On examination, the abdomen is tender without guarding or rebound. There is a draining fistula near her coccyx. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Crohn disease

choices.text: Fall of at least 20 mmHg in systolic blood pressure
Fall of at least 10 mmHg in diastolic BP
Occurs on head-up tilt table testing (HUTT) at an angle of at least 60˚

questions.text: All of the following are correct about definition of postural hypotension except:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Within 10min of active standing

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the OPD due to joint pain and stiffness in both hands for the past 6 months. He sometimes awakens with hand pain at night. Hand radiographs reveal bilateral erosions and joint deformities involving the second and third metacarpophalangeal joints. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hereditary hemochromatosis

 

The diagnosis for the patient with bilateral erosions and joint deformities involving the second and third metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints is hereditary hemochromatosis, especially given the radiographic findings characteristic of this disease.

 

  • Hereditary hemochromatosis arthropathy classically involves the 2nd and 3rd MCP joints, with pain, stiffness, and radiographic changes including:
    • Symmetric joint space narrowing
    • Erosions
    • "Hook-like" or beak-like osteophytes on the radial aspect of metacarpal heads
    • Chondrocalcinosis (calcium pyrophosphate deposition) may also be present.
    • This arthropathy resembles rheumatoid arthritis clinically but is degenerative rather than inflammatory.
    • It typically presents in middle-aged adults and can cause progressive joint damage

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis: Classic for symmetric, erosive polyarthritis of MCP and PIP joints, with progressive joint deformity.

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma: Causes lytic lesions but not joint-centered erosive changes or deformity.

 

Option D. Reactive arthritis: Asymmetric and typically involves lower limb joints, usually not erosive or deforming in hands.

questions.text: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid arthritis patient except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High Glucose

 

In pleural effusion fluid from a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), the following characteristics are typically found except high glucose.

 

  • Low glucose is characteristic, as glucose is consumed by inflammatory cells and bacteria in infected or inflammatory effusions; high glucose is not typical in RA pleural effusions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RA factor: RA factor is often present in pleural fluid due to local immune activity.

 

Option B. Cholesterol crystals: Cholesterol crystals are a classic feature of RA pleural effusions, sometimes termed "pseudo-chylothorax".

 

Option D. High LDH: High LDH is typical, reflecting high inflammatory activity and cell turnover.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to progressive fever and lethargy. The patient has also had severe right shoulder and abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 days. He had an appendectomy during childhood.  Abdominal examination shows generalized tenderness with rebound tenderness. Right shoulder examination is normal. Upright chest x-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Perforated viscus

questions.text: EEG pattern given below is suggestive of which of the following diseases?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Creutzfeldt- Jakob Disease

questions.text: A 45-year-old female suffers from recurrent nonpitting edema of the hands. She often wears warm gloves indoors because her fingers turn blue when they are cold. She also complains of retrosternal burning and regurgitation, especially when supine. Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be found in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Anti-centromere

questions.text: Which of the following factors would suggest a higher risk for a patient with TIA developing stroke in the future according to ABCD2 scoring?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Diabetes

choices.text: Loss of pain sensation in the hands
Loss of position sensation in the fingers
Loss of vibration sensation in the toes

questions.text: 28-year-old man experiences worsening tinnitus and hearing loss. MRI of the brain is shown below. Additional imaging reveals a small meningioma at the C5 spinal level impinging upon the medial portion of the dorsal columns. Which of the following is the most likely earliest clinical manifestation of this lesion?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Loss of vibration sensation in the toes

questions.text: In an animal experiment, the pancreatic duct is cannulated and different secretory stimuli are applied to the gland. The following tracings are obtained by measuring pancreatic fluid constituents. Substance X"' is most likely which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Bicarbonate

questions.text: A patient presents with vertigo, diplopia, hoarseness, dysphagia and left Horner's syndrome associated with numbness of the left face and right-side limbs. Which artery is affected in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Posterior inferior cerebellar artery

choices.text: Regardless of ejection fraction and the type of heart failure, the 5 year mortality rate  is around 50%
Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF-30-40% as compared to HFpEF -15%
(ACE) inhibitors cause cough in 15% and angloedema in 1%
Fib is common in elderly and is the cause of stroke in quarter of the stroke cases

questions.text: All are true regarding heart failure except: (HFpEF- Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction; HFrPF- Heart failure with reduced ejection) fraction:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF-30-40% as compared to HFpEF -15%

choices.text: Calcium current within the atrioventricular node
Calcium current within the sinoatrial node
Sodium current within an atrioventricular accessory pathway

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to palpitations and shortness of breath that began an hour ago. Medical history includes hypertension, coronary artery disease, and paroxysmal atrial flutter. Blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg and pulse is rapid. ECG shows atrial flutter with a ventricular rate of approximately 150/ min. The estimated atrial rate based on ECG flutter waves is 300/min. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the rate difference between the atria and the ventricles?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Calcium current within the atrioventricular node

 

  • The atrioventricular (AV) node controls conduction of electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles and protects the ventricles from excessively rapid rates during atrial arrhythmias like atrial flutter or fibrillation.
  • The AV node relies primarily on slow calcium currents (L-type calcium channels) for depolarization, which limits the conduction rate and causes a ventricular rate slower than the atrial rate (e.g., 2:1 block with atrial flutter rate 300/min and ventricular rate ~150/min).
  • This property accounts for the difference between atrial and ventricular rates seen on ECG.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Calcium current within the sinoatrial node: The SA node initiates normal 

heart rhythm but does not regulate ventricular rate in arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Sodium current within an AV accessory pathway: Accessory pathways conduct impulses via fast sodium channels but are involved in pre-excitation syndromes, not typical atrial flutter block.

 

Option D. Sodium current within the atria: Atrial depolarization depends on sodium current, but this does not determine ventricular rate blocking.

choices.text: Decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic volume

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the OPD due to recurrent episodes of retrosternal chest pain. The episodes occur during physical activity, usually when he climbs stairs or walks uphill, and resolve after he rests for a few minutes. He is prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin to take as needed when the chest pain occurs. This drug is most likely to relieve this patient's symptoms by causing which of the following hemodynamic changes?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decrease in left ventricular end-diastolic volume 

 

  • Sublingual nitroglycerin primarily acts as a venodilator, which decreases preload by reducing venous return to the heart. This decreases left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV), thereby reducing myocardial wall stress and oxygen demand, which relieves angina symptoms.
  • Thus, nitroglycerin relieves symptoms mainly by decreasing LVEDV and myocardial oxygen consumption.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decrease in heart rate: Nitroglycerin may reflexively increase heart rate due to vasodilation.

 

Option C. Decrease in peripheral arteriolar resistance: This is more characteristic of hydralazine; nitroglycerin causes minimal arteriolar dilation at therapeutic doses.

 

Option D. Increase in coronary blood flow: While nitroglycerin dilates epicardial coronary arteries, its main benefit in stable angina is reduction of myocardial oxygen demand through preload reduction.

choices.text: Homogenous acellular thickening of arteriolar walls
Onion-like concentric thickening of arteriolar walls

questions.text: 72-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to persistent headaches, fatigue, and muscle pain. She has a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis. Her father had a subarachnoid hemorrhage from a ruptured berry aneurysm. She is treated with prednisone, leading to marked and rapid improvement in her symptoms. Which of the following pathologic processes is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Granulomatous inflammation of the media

questions.text: The membrane is most permeable to potassium ions at which of the following points?
questions.solution: Ans. D. D

questions.text: A Patient came with sudden onset palpitations. ECG showed narrow complex, regular tachycardia without P waves, and a rate of 160bpm. His BP is 96/68mmHg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Carotid sinus massage

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution: Ans. B. A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2

questions.text: 55-year-old woman is brought to the OPD by her husband for evaluation of strange behavior. She has been spending large amounts of money to buy expensive clothes and jewelry. She usually drinks 1 or 2 glasses of wine on weekends but lately has been drinking 2 or 3 glasses almost every day. This patient's condition is most likely due to abnormal accumulation of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ubiquitinated TDP-43

 

  •  This presentation (late-life disinhibition, compulsive spending → behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia) is commonly associated with neuronal inclusions of ubiquitinated TDP-43.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Ataxin: Ataxin expansions cause spinocerebellar ataxias with progressive cerebellar dysfunction, not a behavioral frontal syndrome.
 

Option B. Beta-amyloid: Beta-amyloid plaques are characteristic of Alzheimer disease, which typically presents with memory loss rather than prominent early behavioral disinhibition.
 

Option C. Prions: Prion diseases (eg, CJD) cause rapidly progressive dementia with myoclonus and other features, not the slowly progressive behavioral variant seen here.

choices.text: Lymphoplasmacytic infiltration of portal and periportal regions
Periductal fibrosis and luminal obliteration of biliary ducts

questions.text:
38-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to jaundice, nausea, and abdominal discomfort. Scleral icterus and hepatomegaly are present. Laboratory results are as follows:

 

Total bilirubin: 4.7 mg/dL

 

Alkaline phosphatase: 110 U/L

 

Aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT): 791 U/L

 

Alanine aminotransferase (SGPT): 634 U/L

 

Anti-smooth muscle antibody titers are elevated. Which of the following histologic findings is most likely to be seen on biopsy of this patient's liver?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Lymphoplasmacytic infiltration of portal and periportal regions

choices.text: Benign flow murmur
Bicuspid aortic valve
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
Pulmonic stenosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravid woman comes to the clinic during the second trimester. The patient reports that she has had some tiredness, which she attributes to pregnancy. She takes 1 nap during the day. She has no chest pain, cough, or lower extremity swelling. As a child, the patient was told that she has a murmur but does not know any details and says that she has felt well until recently. On physical examination, a 3/6 midsystolic murmur is heard at the left upper sternal border and S2 is widely split. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Pulmonic stenosis

questions.text: Calculate the GCS Score in an intubated patient, with findings of eye movements to pain and abnormal flexion?
questions.solution: Ans. D) E2VNTM3

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Bainbridge reflex

questions.text: A triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) EGPA

 

The triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia is characteristic of Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (EGPA) (formerly Churg-Strauss syndrome).

 

  • EGPA is a small to medium vessel vasculitis associated with asthma, eosinophilia, cutaneous manifestations (such as palpable purpura), and neuropathy, specifically mononeuritis multiplex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis: Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis involves immune complex deposition, commonly with purpura and renal involvement but not eosinophilia.

 

Option B. Polyarteritis nodosa: Polyarteritis nodosa typically involves medium vessels with systemic symptoms, but eosinophilia is not a major feature.

 

Option D. Giant cell arteritis: Giant cell arteritis affects large vessels and presents with headache and visual symptoms rather than eosinophilia or mononeuritis multiplex.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man comes to the OPD due to occasional dull headaches that awaken him from sleep. The patient has no associated neurologic deficits. On physical examination, there are several 3 cm to 5 cm flat, pigmented spots on his trunk. There are also multiple, subcentimeter, soft, fleshy, cutaneous tumors located on his trunk and neck. The predominant cells forming these tumors most likely originated from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neural crest

 

This patient's findings (multiple cutaneous neurofibromas and café-au-lait spots) are classic for Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). The predominant cells forming neurofibromas (Schwann cells) originate from the neural crest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm:

 

  • Gives rise to epithelial lining of GI tract, respiratory tract, and associated glands.
  • Does not contribute to cutaneous tumors or neural tissue.
  • Unrelated to the pathogenesis of neurofibromas.

 

Option B. Mesoderm:

 

  • Forms muscle, bone, connective tissue, and blood vessels.
  • Not the source of Schwann cells or melanocytes in skin lesions.
  • Provides structural support but not the neural elements here.

 

Option D. Neural tube:

 

  • Gives rise to central nervous system neurons and glial cells.
  • Does not form peripheral nerves or Schwann cells.
  • Involved in CNS but not in cutaneous neurofibromas.

questions.text: Identify the type of ANA staining pattern shown in the image below:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Centromeric

questions.text:
In atrial fibrillation, choose the correct statements:

 

  1. Novel oral anticoagulants (NOACs) used in the treatment of moderate to severe MS
  2. Anticoagulants should be given in patients with ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation
  3. NOACs are contraindicated in prosthetic valves
  4. All patients with atrial fibrillation who are not candidates for cardiac surgery can be started on beta-blockers
questions.solution: Ans. C) 2 and 3 correct

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman is brought to the hospital due to respiratory difficulty. She has had trouble performing her daily activities for the past few weeks due to fatigue. In particular, her arms seem to "just drop" when she combs her hair or brushes her teeth. The patient's symptoms are generally better in the morning and worsen throughout the day.  Which of the following is most likely abnormal in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Number of acetylcholine receptors

questions.text: What is the most probable location of the lesion in the patient shown below?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Right posterior parietal area

questions.text: At which stage of the cardiac cycle is an Aortic Regurgitation murmur expected to be audible?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Ventricular diastole

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician due to periodic reddening of her skin that is starting to become bothersome. The patient has also had persistent watery diarrhea and associated abdominal cramping for the last several months. Physical examination shows several, purple vascular lesions surrounding her nose. Urinary excretion of 5- hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) over 24 hours is increased. Abdominal imaging shows a tumor in the small intestine. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metastatic carcinoid


Carcinoid syndrome (flushing, watery diarrhea, bronchospasm, right-sided valvular lesions) occurs when serotonin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors metastasize to the liver (or originate outside the portal system), allowing vasoactive substances to bypass hepatic first-pass metabolism; elevated urinary 5-HIAA confirms excessive serotonin production. A small-intestinal carcinoid that has metastasized to the liver is the classic cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Localized adenocarcinoma: Adenocarcinomas of the small bowel generally do not secrete serotonin and do not cause carcinoid syndrome.

 

Option B. Localized carcinoid: If confined to the gut without hepatic metastases, secreted serotonin is metabolized by the liver and usually does not produce systemic carcinoid syndrome.

 

Option D. Metastatic lymphoma: Lymphomas may involve the bowel but do not cause serotonin-mediated flushing/diarrhea or elevated 5-HIAA.

questions.text:
Arrange the following phases of cardiac cycle in sequential order from systole to diastole:

 

1. S1

2. S4

3. y descent

4. R wave
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 4-1-3-2

 

Events given:

 

  1. S1 – first heart sound → due to closure of AV valves at the start of systole.
  2. S4 – atrial contraction sound (“atrial kick”) → occurs in late diastole, just before S1.
  3. y descent – fall in atrial pressure due to opening of AV valves and ventricular filling → early diastole.
  4. R wave – ECG ventricular depolarization → precedes ventricular systole, occurs just before S1.

 

Correct Sequence:

 

  • R wave (4) → ventricular depolarization → onset of systole.
  • S1 (1) → closure of AV valves → marks start of ventricular systole.
  • y descent (3) → rapid ventricular filling → early diastole.
  • S4 (2) → atrial contraction at end of diastole (presystolic).

 

So, sequence = 4 → 1 → 3 → 2

 

MNEMONIC : Pa4 QRS 1Cx T2dn v3y

questions.text: 24-year-old man comes to the OPD due to severe pain in the posterior aspect of the right foot that interferes with walking. For the last several months, the patient has also experienced a dull backache and morning stiffness that is relieved by over-the-counter ibuprofen. Which of the following is the most probable location of the pathologic process responsible for this patient's foot pain?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Tendon insertion site

questions.text:
A patient presented to the casualty with right sided hemiparesis and aphasia for a duration of one hour. Identify the correct statements:

 

  1. rTPA will not be used if CT scan is normal

  2. Tenecteplase should not be used if BP is 160/90 mm Hg

  3. CT angiography is the initial investigation of choice

  4. rTPA contraindicated if edema is more than 1/3rd of middle cerebral artery territory
questions.solution: Ans. D) 4

questions.text: 52-year-old man comes to the OPD for a painless mass in his right groin. He noticed the mass several weeks ago, and it has slowly enlarged. On examination, several enlarged, hard lymph nodes are palpated in the right inguinal area inferior to the inguinal ligament. An excisional biopsy is performed, and histopathology shows malignant cells. The malignant cells found in this patient most likely originated from which of the following sites?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Orifice of the anal canal

questions.text: 68-year-old man comes to the OPD due to difficulty performing normal day-to-day activities with his hands. He has had pain in his finger joints, wrists, and knees for many years and has been taking over- the-counter analgesics Examination findings of the patient's hands are shown in the image below. Which of the following pathogenic mechanisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Synovial pannus formation

questions.text: 54-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to exertional dyspnea and fatigue. The patient gets short of breath while walking to a store 2 blocks away from her home. She also has trouble breathing at night and sleeps with 2 or 3 pillows to prop her up. She has had occasional palpitations but no chest pain. After initial evaluation, she is scheduled for a left heart catheterization, the findings of which are shown below What is the likely diagnosis.
questions.solution: Ans. D) MR

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented with a history of bilateral lower limb weakness which progressed to his upper limbs in a year. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the left upper limb. Babinski sign was positive and the deep tendon reflexes were absent. He has no sensory loss or any autonomic dysfunction. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) ALS (Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis)

choices.text: Pericardial inflammation due to autoimmune reaction to necrotic tissue
Pericardial inflammation due to concomitant viral infection
Pericardial inflammation overlying the necrotic segment of myocardium
Recurrent thrombosis of the culprit coronary vessel

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with an acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction. The patient undergoes coronary angiography with stent placement in the left circumflex artery, and he is started on therapy with a beta blocker and antiplatelet agents. On day 3 of hospitalization he experiences chest pain. The pain, described as sharp and radiating to his neck and shoulders, is exacerbated by coughing and swallowing. Temperature is 37.5 C (99.5 °F), blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min and regular, and respirations are 20/min. The lungs are clear on auscultation. There is no peripheral edema. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's chest pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pericardial inflammation overlying the necrotic segment of myocardium

 

  • The patient developed sharp, pleuritic chest pain within days after an acute myocardial infarction (MI). This is typical of early (acute) pericarditis resulting from inflammation of the pericardium adjacent to the necrotic myocardium.
  • It usually occurs within the first few days (1-4 days) after MI and is characterized by chest pain worsened by coughing, swallowing, or deep breaths.
  • Fever and clear lung auscultation also support pericarditis rather than heart failure or recurrent ischemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pericardial inflammation due to autoimmune reaction to necrotic tissue: Autoimmune reaction (Dressler syndrome): Occurs weeks to months post-MI, a delayed immune-mediated pericarditis.

 

Option B. Pericardial inflammation due to concomitant viral infection: Viral infection: Less likely in the immediate post-MI setting without other signs.

 

Option D. Recurrent thrombosis of the culprit coronary vessel: Would cause typical angina pain, not sharp pleuritic pain and would likely worsen hemodynamics.

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.text: The rise in blood pressure that occurs at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is a result of?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.text: A highly agitated 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his family because he is unable to effectively communicate. He speaks clearly and with conviction but his sentences are incomprehensible. He does not appear to understand the doctor's questions, does not follow oral or written instructions, and cannot repeat simple phrases. Branch occlusion of which of the following arteries is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left Middle cerebral artery-inferior division

 

  •  The patient has Wernicke’s aphasia (fluent but nonsensical speech, impaired comprehension, inability to repeat). This localizes to the posterior superior temporal gyrus in the dominant (usually left) hemisphere, supplied by the inferior division of the left MCA.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Right MCA – superior division: Would affect motor cortex (contralateral face/arm weakness), not language in a right-handed person.


Option B. Right MCA – inferior division: Would not cause aphasia since the right hemisphere is usually non-dominant for language.


Option C. Left MCA – superior division: Causes Broca’s aphasia (nonfluent speech with good comprehension), not fluent but meaningless speech.

choices.text: Total lack of natural killer cells
Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: Which of the subsequent statements accurately describes the immunological anomaly associated with the absence of CD40 in B cells?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Decrease in lgG and increase in lgM

questions.text:
What characteristics define necrosis among the options provided?

1. Disrupted cell membrane

2. Induces inflammation

3. Swelling of the cell

4. Can be seen physiologically
questions.solution: Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

questions.text: Which of the following is not a major diagnostic criterion of neuromyelitis optica?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Focal epilepsy

questions.text: In an experiment investigating vasoconstriction of the arterial wall, two samples of isolated porcine arterial vessels are studied. Vascular tone is measured in the control vessel during infusion of increasing doses of norepinephrine. The other vessel is pretreated with experimental drug A prior to infusion of norepinephrine. A graph of the study results is depicted below. Drug A is most similar to which of the following agents?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Phenoxybenzamine

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is being evaluated for difficulty walking. On physical examination, he has thoracic scoliosis and multiple small scars on his hands. When asked about these, the boy replies, "I frequently burn my hands by accident because I can't feel the heat." Neurologic examination reveals 1+ biceps reflexes and 3+ patellar reflexes bilaterally, as well as decreased muscle strength in the bilateral upper and lower extremities. His hand muscles are atrophic, and position and vibration senses in the feet are also impaired. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's problems?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Syringomyelia

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation comes to the OPD due to numbness of his left hand for the past 3 weeks. When the eyes are closed, he is unable to recognize the letters written on his left hand with a stylus. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+. Gait is normal. This patient most likely has a lesion in which of the following locations of the brain?
questions.solution: Ans. A. A

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the office due to exertional dyspnea. The patient has a history of lgA nephropathy; she received hemodialysis for 2 years before undergoing kidney transplantation last month. Chest x-ray reveals cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion. Further evaluation determines that her symptoms are likely due to persistence of the arteriovenous fistula that was used for hemodialysis. Which of the following physiologic changes in 1) cardiac output, 2) systemic vascular resistance and 3) venous return respectively are present in this patient due to the fistula?
questions.solution: Ans. D. increases, decreases, increases

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Troponin - T

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the OPD for treatment of anxiety that has worsened over the past year. She says, "My anxiety just comes out of the blue; one way or another, I'm anxious all the time.  An anxiety disorder is diagnosed and fluoxetine is prescribed. The patient's anxiety begins to improve over the next 4-6 weeks. The physician explains that the medication inhibits the reuptake of a neurotransmitter released by a specific set of neurons. These neurons are likely part of which of the following structures?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Raphe nuclei

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student developed epistaxis that resolved spontaneously. He has been afebrile for the last 24 hours and his platelet count is 14,000/uL. His BP is 110/70 mm of Hg and there is a 28% rise in hematocrit. What should be the management?

 

 

  1. Give 4 units of platelets
  2. Give plenty of oral fluids
  3. Give IV fluids
  4. Keep under observation
  5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution: Ans. B. 2, 3, and 4

questions.text: 34-year-old woman comes to the physician due to weakness, exertional dyspnea, and orthopnea. On cardiac auscultation, a snap followed by a rumbling diastolic murmur is heard over the cardiac apex. The snap most likely occurs nearest to which of the following points on the cardiac pressure-volume loop?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

  • The patient has classic signs of mitral stenosis: a snap (opening snap) followed by a rumbling diastolic murmur at the cardiac apex.
  • The opening snap occurs just after the mitral valve opens, which corresponds to the point where left ventricular pressure falls below left atrial pressure—this is point D on the pressure-volume loop, marking the start of diastolic filling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitral valve closure (beginning of systole)

 

Option B. Aortic valve opening (start of ejection)

 

Option C. Aortic valve closure (end of ejection)

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded
Inability to contract the right orbicularis oculi muscle
Vision defect affecting the left half of the visual field
Weakness of the right lateral rectus muscle

questions.text: 35-year-old woman with a history of migraines is evaluated due to a recent increase in headache frequency and severity. She has had no focal weakness, sensory loss, vision changes, or seizures. Neuroimaging reveals a small aneurysm arising from the segment of right internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus. If this patient's aneurysm continues to expand, which of the following findings is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Weakness of the right lateral rectus muscle

 

  •  An aneurysm of the internal carotid artery within the cavernous sinus can compress cranial nerves III, IV, V1, V2, and VI. The abducens nerve (CN VI) is most vulnerable due to its medial location, leading to impaired lateral rectus function (inability to abduct the eye).

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded: Caused by right hypoglossal (CN XII) palsy, not affected in the cavernous sinus.


Option B. Inability to contract the right orbicularis oculi muscle: Due to facial nerve (CN VII) palsy, which does not traverse the cavernous sinus.


Option C. Vision defect affecting the left half of the visual field: Suggests a lesion of the right optic tract; not caused by cavernous sinus pathology.

questions.text: Which of the following pathologic findings is associated with the greatest risk of malignant transformation in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C

choices.text: Cardiac free wall rupture
Ventricular septal rupture

questions.text: 57-year-old unconscious man is brought to the emergency department by his wife. Thirty minutes prior, the patient developed severe chest pain and asked to be taken to the hospital. On the way, he became unresponsive. In the emergency department, the patient has no spontaneous respirations or circulation and is pronounced dead. An autopsy examination is performed, and a cross-section of the mid-right coronary artery is shown in the exhibit. Which of the following is the most likely immediate cause of death in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to involuntary movements of his right arm that started several hours ago. He was watching television when his arm "threw the remote control across the room." His past medical history is significant for long- standing hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Physical examination shows wild, large-amplitude, flinging movements affecting the proximal muscles of his right arm. Which of the following areas of the brain is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Subthalamic nucleus

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the ECG given below?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Multifocal atrial tachycardia

questions.text: A 14-month-old girl is brought to the OPD due to a 2-month history of diarrhea. Her parents report that she has 3-5 loose, nonbloody bowel movements daily with occasional episodes of vomiting. She was breastfed exclusively until age 9 months and has since had a well-varied diet including whole milk, fruits, vegetables, bread, and meats. However, the girl has been less interested in food over the past several weeks. Biopsy findings are shown. Which of the following would most likely improve this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Modified grain diet

questions.text: Identify the given ECG.
questions.solution: Ans. A) Torsades de pointes

questions.text: 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her son after he found her acting strangely. She was asking to open the window blinds, even though the blinds were already open and was bumping into objects when walking around her home. The patient insists that her vision is fine and came to the hospital upon her son’s insistence. Bilateral direct and consensual pupillary reflexes are normal. On confrontation visual field testing, she reports the wrong number of fingers In all ” vis’al quadrants. The patient indicates the wrong direction when asked to point to the door and gives an incorrect visual description when asked to describe the physician. This patient most likely has an infarction involving the brain regions supplied by which of the following arteries?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Posterior cerebral artery

questions.text: A 6-year-old male child was presented with a past of persistent cough and foul-smelling stools. His sibling, who had experienced comparable symptoms, passed away a few years earlier. Tests including the sweat chloride test and CFTR gene analysis were conducted and cystic fibrosis was diagnosed. What will happen to the transport of Chloride ions in sweat gland and pancreatic ducts respectively?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Decrease, decrease

questions.text: After successfully overcoming a hepatitis B infection, the patient's immune system generated antibodies. Which of the curves presented below depicts the levels of these antibodies observed four weeks after the recovery?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Anti-HBs

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is being evaluated due to several weeks of watery diarrhea. He has also had intermittent, crampy abdominal pain and has lost 7 kg during this period. The patient has a history of HIV and was hospitalized 6 months ago for Pneumocystis pneumonia. Stool tests for leukocytes and occult blood are negative. Endoscopy is performed, and mucosal biopsy is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Cryptosporidium parvum

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the OPD with several months of vision problems, difficulty chewing, and trouble speaking. The symptoms fluctuate, but the patient has noticed that they are worse after a long day. Regarding her symptoms, she says, "It's probably just exhaustion; an ice pack to my face seems to help."  The pathogenesis of this patient's disease is most similar to which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Goodpasture syndrome

questions.text: What among the following does not contribute to reversible dementia?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Lewy body dementia

choices.text: Decreasing intestinal absorption of copper

questions.text: A 12 year old male child brought by his parents with complaints of, his school performance has declined, and he has been moodier and more impulsive. His parents also note that he has been sleeping more than usual and has had a poor appetite for the past 2 months. Approximately 3 weeks ago, the patient developed a tremor in both hands that is most prominent when he reaches for an object or tries to write. The tremor has worsened significantly over the past week, and he has developed an unsteady, broad-based gait. Laboratory studies reveal elevated serum transaminases and 24-hour urinary copper excretion. The patient is prescribed penicillamine therapy. This medication primarily works through which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Increasing urinary excretion of copper

questions.text: A 34-year-old man develops severe chest and abdominal pain while shopping in a mall. Paramedics arrive and find him in severe distress. Several minutes later, he suffers a cardiac arrest with pulseless electrical activity and cannot be resuscitated. Postmortem examination reveals an internal hemorrhage as the cause of death. Histochemical evaluation of the patient's tissues reveals a defect affecting a large extracellular glycoprotein. This protein is normally found abundantly in large blood vessels, periosteum, and zonular fibers of the lens and functions to form microfibrils by surrounding elastin. This patient most likely suffered from which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Marfan syndrome

 

  • The defect described is in a large extracellular glycoprotein that forms microfibrils surrounding elastin, which is fibrillin-1. Fibrillin-1 is a major component of microfibrils in connective tissue and is abundant in large blood vessels, periosteum, and zonular fibers of the lens.
  • Mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene leads to Marfan syndrome, characterized by skeletal abnormalities, lens dislocation, and aortic root aneurysm prone to dissection and fatal hemorrhage.
  • The patient's sudden death due to internal hemorrhage from a blood vessel rupture fits the classic presentation of aortic dissection in Marfan syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ehlers-Danlos syndrome: Due to collagen defects, not fibrillin, and presents with skin hyperextensibility and joint hypermobility.

 

Option B. Homocystinuria: Also causes lens dislocation but classically inferiorly; presents with Marfanoid habitus but has elevated homocysteine.

 

Option D. Osteogenesis imperfecta: Affects type I collagen causing brittle bones but no vascular microfibril defect.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to your OPD with severe nausea and recurrent bilious vomiting. Her symptoms initially began as postprandial epigastric pain and early satiety, but have progressed over the last two weeks. She works as an actress, and tells you that her symptoms only started when she "landed a role in a TV serial" and was inspired to lose 15kgs. on a "crash diet". On physical exam, her abdomen is tender and slightly distended with high-pitched bowel sounds. A laparotomy is performed, and it is observed that the angle between her superior mesenteric artery and her aorta is significantly decreased. Which of the following structures is most likely to be obstructed by the artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transverse portion of the duodenum

 

This describes Superior Mesenteric Artery Syndrome (Wilkie’s syndrome), where rapid weight loss leads to loss of mesenteric fat pad, decreasing the angle between SMA and the aorta. This narrows the aortomesenteric space and compresses the third (transverse/horizontal) part of the duodenum, leading to bilious vomiting, abdominal pain, and gastric outlet obstruction–like symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ascending portion of the duodenum: This is the fourth part, which ascends to the duodenojejunal flexure. It is not compressed between SMA and aorta.

 

Option B. Descending portion of the duodenum: This second part lies vertically along the right side of the vertebral column and receives the bile and pancreatic ducts; it is not in the path of SMA compression.

 

Option C. Duodenal bulb: The first part (duodenal bulb) lies anterior to the portal triad and is commonly affected in peptic ulcer disease, but not compressed by SMA.

questions.text: 34-year-old woman with sleep problems comes to the OPD. Over the last year, she has had increasing difficulty falling asleep at night and is exhausted during the day. The patient does not use alcohol, tobacco, or illicit drugs. She has a family history of heart disease and depression. The patient has failed a number of nonpharmacological approaches, including cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia. She requests pharmacologic treatment and is prescribed a short course of zolpidem. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of action of this medication?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GABA receptor agonism

 

  •  Zolpidem is a non-benzodiazepine hypnotic (“Z-drug”) that selectively binds the GABA-A receptor at the benzodiazepine site, enhancing chloride influx and promoting sleep.

 

Opter Options:

 

Option A. Dopamine receptor antagonism: Mechanism of antipsychotics, not hypnotics.


Option C. Histamine receptor antagonism: Seen with sedating antihistamines (eg, diphenhydramine, doxylamine), not zolpidem.


Option D. Melatonin receptor agonism: Mechanism of drugs like ramelteon, not zolpidem.

questions.text: 45-year-old man comes to the clinic due to a 2-month history of progressive left arm clumsiness and weakness. The patient initially attributed his symptoms to a left rotator cuff injury he sustained several years ago; however, he has recently developed problems with his gait. He has had no recent injury, headaches, or bowel/bladder symptoms. On physical examination, there is reduced muscle strength in the left upper extremity. Further evaluation with brain MRI reveals a lesion involving the corticospinal tract. Which of the following additional signs is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Hyperactive deep tendon reflexes

questions.text: The absence of loud S1 in mitral stenosis would indicate all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mild mitral stenosis

 

  • The loud S1 in mitral stenosis is due to the forceful closure of a still mobile, but stenotic mitral valve.
  • Usually retains a normal or loud S1 because the valve is not yet heavily affected or immobile.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcified valve: If the valve is heavily calcified and immobile, S1 is often diminished or absent because the valve closes less forcefully.

 

Option B. Aortic regurgitation: Can cause premature mitral valve closure, blunting the loudness of S1.

 

Option C. First degree heart block: Delays atrioventricular conduction, causing the mitral valve to close with less force, reducing S1 intensity. Therefore, absence of loud S1 would not be expected in mild mitral stenosis.

questions.text:
You are posted as an intern in casualty. An elderly 60-year-old man is brought to you with complaints of chest pain. He has tested positive for COVID. Which of the following features will prompt you to get this patient admitted to dedicated COVID health centre?

 

  1. Respiratory rate of 25/min
  2. SpO2 93%
  3. Multiple comorbidities
  4. Age
questions.solution: Ans. B. A, B, C, D

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on physical examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left dysdiadochokinesia

 

  • The MRI shows a lesion in the left cerebellar hemisphere.
  • The cerebellum is responsible for coordination of movement, and lesions here cause ipsilateral (same side) cerebellar signs due to double crossing of cerebellar pathways.
  • Dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid alternating movements) is a hallmark of cerebellar dysfunction and would occur on the left side due to a left cerebellar lesion.
  • Horner’s syndrome, hemiparesis, and hemisensory loss are not typical effects of isolated cerebellar lesions.

questions.text:
Serologic findings of a patient with hepatitis are given below.

 

HBsAg positive

 

Anti-HBc lgG positive

 

Anti-HDV IgM positive

 

Titer of HBV DNA - 7.4 X 10

 

Titer of HDV DNA - 4.1 X 10

 

Which of the following is most useful in diagnosing HDV superinfection over coinfection?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Anti-HBc IgG positivity

questions.text: Identify the conduction abnormality from the ECG given below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mobitz type 1

 

  • The ECG shows gradually increasing PR intervals until a beat is dropped (a P wave not followed by a QRS complex), and then the cycle repeats. This classic pattern is characteristic of Mobitz type 1 (Wenckebach) second-degree AV block.

  • Thus, the conduction abnormality is Mobitz type 1[Wencheback].

     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First degree heart block: Consistently prolonged PR interval with no dropped beats.

 

Option C. Third degree heart block: Complete dissociation of P waves and QRS complexes, with no relation between them.

 

Option D. Mobitz type 2: Sudden dropped QRS complexes without preceding gradual PR prolongation.

questions.text:
6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents with a 2-day history of fever and headaches. The parents report that he vomited once this afternoon. All of his vaccinations are up-to-date. Examination shows mild pharyngeal erythema in addition to neck stiffness. Cerebrospinal fluid analysis reveals the following:

 

Glucose 70mg/dl

 

Protein 85 mg/dl

 

Leukocytes 300/mm3

 

Neutrophils: 15%

 

Lymphocytes: 85%

 

Red blood cells: none

 

Which of the following infectious agents is most likely to have caused this patient's illness?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Enterovirus

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is evaluated for recurrent infections. He was born at term after a normal pregnancy. His mother states, "He is always sick with something and is constantly on antibiotics." The patient's past medical records indicate multiple episodes of otitis media, skin infections, and pneumonia. Incision and drainage of his skin infections revealed Staphylococcus aureus on bacterial culture but no purulence. Laboratory testing reveals absent CD18 antigens on the surface of leukocytes. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Persistent leukocytosis

 

The patient has Leukocyte Adhesion Deficiency (LAD-1) due to absent CD18. Neutrophils cannot migrate to infection sites, leading to persistent high WBC counts despite ongoing infections.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Infection following live-virus vaccines: Seen in T-cell immunodeficiencies

 

Option B. Infection with Neisseria: Seen in complement deficiencies.

 

Option D. Small or absent lymph nodes: Seen in X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

questions.text: Identify the pattern of involvement in Vitamin E deficiency:
questions.solution: Ans. B)

choices.text: The earth to all leads is in the right leg
Lead I: Positive pole to the right and negative pole towards the left
Lead II: Positive pole on the left arm and negative pole towards the right leg
Lead II: Positive pole on the right and negative pole towards the left

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the placement of ECG leads?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The earth to all leads is in the right leg

 

The earth (neutral) electrode is commonly placed on the right leg to serve as a reference point and reduce electrical interference in ECG recordings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lead I: The positive pole is on the left arm and the negative pole on the right arm, not the other way around.

 

Option C. Lead II: The positive pole is on the left leg and negative pole on the right arm.

 

Option D. Lead II: The positive pole is not on the right; it is on the left leg.

choices.text: High titors of antistreptolysin O antibodies
Positive serum antinuclear antibodies

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the clinic with acute right knee pain and swelling. His symptoms have been present for a week and have moderately worsened over this period. The patient is able to bear weight but has significant pain when climbing stairs or walking for extended distances. Past medical history is unremarkable, though the patient was seen by his primary care provider for a diarrheal illness 2 weeks before onset of the current symptoms. Examination shows a moderate-sized effusion at the right knee. Cultures of a joint aspirate reveal no bacteria. Which of the following is most likely associated with this patient's joint symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Histocompatibility antigen HLA-B27

questions.text: An 11-year-old child diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever and having no valvular pathology comes to your clinic. What is the duration of prophylaxis given to this child?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 10 years

questions.text: 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for refusal to move his right arm. This afternoon, he tripped while holding hands with his sister, who pulled up on his arm to prevent him from falling. On physical examination, he holds the right arm against his abdomen with the elbow flexed and forearm pronated. The patient cries with any attempted manipulation of the right elbow. There is no visible swelling or deformity. Which of the following structures is most likely affected in this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Annular ligament
